Chad Bohannan wrote:

> I'm picking apart the Windows NEAT code I have, and mulling over some 
> of the threads from the group, and I have some questions.
>
> innovation #s vs ID #s: are they the same thing? I see some code 
> readability to using unique id numbers, but I don't understand what 
> innovation #s are for. I was reading postings about remembering all 
> the innovations. what benifit does this have?


Hi Chad, it's probably best if you read one Ken's papers to get a 
grounding on this sort of stuff, but I will try and summarise. It's 
easisest for me to discuss the workings of SharpNEAT, but most of the 
fundamental workings are shared with Ken's and other implementations.

Genomes can be compared with each other and a compatibility number 
generated. NEAT defines a compatibility threshold number so that genomes 
that are closeley matched (compatible) will be placed into the same 
species. To do a comparison though would normally require us to compare 
the two genome's topology - which is difficult to do and expensive. So 
in order to eliminate the need for topology matching every gene is 
allocated a unique innovation ID, this ID is passed on when genomes 
spawn offspring via asexual reproduction and crossover, etc. So now we 
can compare two genomes by matching up genes with the same innovation ID.

Now, in SharpNEAT genomes are made up from NeuronGenes and 
ConnectionGenes and both types have an innovation ID allocated. The 
genome comparison algorithm though only looks at ConnectionGenes because 
they describe the topology perfectly well without the NeuronGenes. The 
NeuronGene innovation ID therefore isn't actually used as an innovation 
ID, the ID is just a convienient number that we can use within the 
ConnectionGene to describe which two neurons are being connected.

>
> genotype vs phenotype: I know there has been a lot of talk and 
> interest in modular structures, where the phenotype is not a direct 
> mapping of the genotype, but if ( as in with NEAT ) the phenotype IS a 
> direct map, wouldn't it be simpler not to seperate the two? 

I think there is a performance benefit in merging the two since this 
would eliminate the need to 'decode' the genome into a network. I took 
the decision to keep them seperate because I plan to experiment with 
different genome encodings - and anyway IMO it's good programming 
practice to keep the two concepts decoupled as much as possible.

>
> species: can speciation be summarized as method of evolving multiple 
> populations simultaniously, or is there too much mixing between 
> species? I havn't read too deep into the speciation code. I don't 
> really grasp what it's supposed to accomplish. Windows NEAT 
> essentially seems to use the species class as a simple container with 
> accessors. Is that it?

There is more to it than that. New species are spawned when offspring 
are sufficiently different to not fit into the parent species. Also, 
some implementations have a dynamic compatibility threshold - when this 
changes (in sharpNEAT) the population is re-speciated. Also note that a 
small amount of cross-species reproduction occurs in some implementations.

It's all covered in various papers. The concept is a simple one but very 
effective.

Colin.
